title: Isaiah Chapter 66 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 66 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 66 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 66.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:1, what does the LORD say is His throne?
options: The heaven
The earth
The temple
The mountain
questions.correctAnswer: The heaven
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:1 states, 'The heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool.'

questions.question: In Isaiah 66:2, to whom will the LORD look?
options: The rich and powerful
The poor and contrite in spirit
The priests and Levites
The kings and rulers
questions.correctAnswer: The poor and contrite in spirit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:2 says, 'but to this man will I look, even to him that is poor and of a contrite spirit.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:3, how does God compare killing an ox?
options: As if he slew a dog
As if he slew a man
As if he cut off a lamb's neck
As if he blessed an idol
questions.correctAnswer: As if he slew a man
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:3 states, 'He that killeth an ox is as if he slew a man.'

questions.question: What will the LORD bring upon those who did evil before Him according to Isaiah 66:4?
options: Peace and joy
Delusions and fears
Riches and honor
Forgiveness and mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Delusions and fears
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:4 says, 'I also will choose their delusions, and will bring their fears upon them; because when I called, none did answer.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 66:5 says that those who tremble at the word of the LORD will be ashamed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:5 states that those who tremble at His word will rejoice while their brethren who hated them shall be ashamed.

questions.question: What kind of voice is described in Isaiah 66:6?
options: A voice of praise
A voice of noise from the city
A voice of peace
A voice of angels
questions.correctAnswer: A voice of noise from the city
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:6 describes 'A voice of noise from the city, a voice from the temple, a voice of the LORD.'

questions.question: Complete the phrase from Isaiah 66:7: 'Before she travailed, she brought forth; before her pain came, she was delivered of a ______.'
options: woman
man child
lamb
king
questions.correctAnswer: man child
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:7 states, 'Before she travailed, she brought forth; before her pain came, she was delivered of a man child.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:8, what is compared to a nation being born at once?
options: The earth bringing forth in one day
The mountains shaking
The temple being rebuilt
The river flowing
questions.correctAnswer: The earth bringing forth in one day
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:8 asks, 'Shall the earth be made to bring forth in one day? or shall a nation be born at once?'

questions.question: What does the LORD say He will not do in Isaiah 66:9?
options: Bring to birth and not cause to bring forth
Forgive sins
Destroy the earth
Forget His people
questions.correctAnswer: Bring to birth and not cause to bring forth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:9 says, 'Shall I bring to the birth, and not cause to bring forth? saith the LORD.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 66:10 calls all who love Jerusalem to mourn with her.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:10 says, 'Rejoice ye with Jerusalem, and be glad with her, all ye that love her: rejoice for joy with her, all ye that mourn for her.'

questions.question: In Isaiah 66:12, what is the peace to Jerusalem compared to?
options: A river
A mountain
A fire
A star
questions.correctAnswer: A river
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:12 says, 'Behold, I will extend peace to her like a river.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:13, how will the LORD comfort His people?
options: As a father comforts his son
As one whom his mother comforteth
With riches and honor
With songs and dances
questions.correctAnswer: As one whom his mother comforteth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:13 states, 'As one whom his mother comforteth, so will I comfort you.'

questions.question: What will the LORD come with according to Isaiah 66:15?
options: Fire and chariots like a whirlwind
Peace and mercy
Rain and thunder
Angels and trumpets
questions.correctAnswer: Fire and chariots like a whirlwind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:15 says, 'For, behold, the LORD will come with fire, and with his chariots like a whirlwind.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 66:16 states the LORD will plead with all flesh by fire and by sword.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:16 says, 'For by fire and by his sword will the LORD plead with all flesh.'

questions.question: Who shall be consumed together according to Isaiah 66:17?
options: Those who sanctify and purify themselves in the gardens
The poor and contrite in spirit
The righteous and the faithful
The kings and priests
questions.correctAnswer: Those who sanctify and purify themselves in the gardens
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:17 states, 'They that sanctify themselves, and purify themselves in the gardens... shall be consumed together.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 66 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 66 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is feeling insignificant in their faith journey. Based on Isaiah 66:2, what biblical truth would you share about how God views a humble and contrite spirit?
options: God looks with favor on those who are poor and contrite in spirit
God only values those who perform great miracles
God prefers those with wealth and power
God ignores the humble and contrite
questions.correctAnswer: God looks with favor on those who are poor and contrite in spirit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:2 clearly states that the LORD looks to the one who is poor and of a contrite spirit, who trembles at His word. This teaches us the value of humility and reverence before God. Supporting verses include Isaiah 66:5 about those who tremble at His word, Isaiah 66:13 about God comforting like a mother, and Isaiah 66:14 about rejoicing in the LORD's care.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 66:3-4 warn believers about the importance of sincere obedience rather than empty rituals?
options: God rejects offerings and sacrifices when hearts are not right
God accepts all sacrifices regardless of heart condition
Rituals are more important than actions
Only the quantity of sacrifices matters
questions.correctAnswer: God rejects offerings and sacrifices when hearts are not right
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 4 emphasize that those who perform sacrifices but do evil and choose their own ways are despised by God. True obedience requires hearing and responding to God's call, not empty ritual. This aligns with the principle of faith and obedience throughout scripture, as also seen in Isaiah 66:5-6 about revering God's word.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by persecution for their faith. According to Isaiah 66:5, what encouragement does this passage offer?
options: The LORD will appear to bring joy and shame the haters
Persecutors will always succeed in discouraging believers
Believers should avoid conflict at all costs
God will ignore those who suffer for His name
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will appear to bring joy and shame the haters
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:5 provides comfort that those who tremble at God's word and are persecuted for His name will see the LORD bring joy to them and shame to their enemies. This shows God’s faithfulness in trials and encourages perseverance. Related verses include Isaiah 66:6 about recompense to enemies and Isaiah 66:14 about rejoicing and flourishing.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 66:7-8 teach us about God’s power to bring forth new beginnings even before difficulties arise?
options: God can bring forth a nation suddenly, before labor pains
New things come only after long struggle and pain
God is limited by natural timing
Birth and growth are entirely human efforts
questions.correctAnswer: God can bring forth a nation suddenly, before labor pains
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:7-8 describes Zion bringing forth children before labor pains, symbolizing God's sovereign power to bring about new beginnings unexpectedly and miraculously. This encourages faith and trust in God’s timing and power. Supporting verses include Isaiah 66:9 about God causing to bring forth and Isaiah 66:10-12 about rejoicing and peace.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 66:10-13 illustrate God’s comfort and peace for His people during times of mourning?
options: God comforts His people like a mother and provides abundant peace
God leaves His people to mourn without comfort
Only human efforts can bring comfort
Peace comes from ignoring troubles
questions.correctAnswer: God comforts His people like a mother and provides abundant peace
questions.explanation: These verses assure us that God will comfort His people as a mother comforts her child and will extend peace like a river. This teaches believers to rely on God’s tender care amid trials. Isaiah 66:13 explicitly likens God's comfort to a mother's, while verses 11-12 describe satisfaction and abundance from His glory.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:14-16, how should believers understand God's judgment in relation to His servants and enemies?
options: God's hand is known in blessing His servants and judging His enemies with fire
God will ignore evil and not punish enemies
God's judgment is always delayed and uncertain
Believers will face the same judgment as enemies
questions.correctAnswer: God's hand is known in blessing His servants and judging His enemies with fire
questions.explanation: Verses 14-16 describe God’s judgment coming with fire and fury against enemies, while His servants will rejoice and flourish. This teaches that God is just and faithful, protecting and rewarding the obedient. The imagery of fire symbolizes purification and retribution, reinforcing the call for holiness.

questions.question: A believer struggles with temptation to follow false religious practices. What warning does Isaiah 66:17 give about such actions?
options: Those who sanctify themselves with abominable practices will be consumed
God accepts all religious practices equally
False rituals lead to blessings
God overlooks hidden sins
questions.correctAnswer: Those who sanctify themselves with abominable practices will be consumed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:17 warns that those who purify themselves by eating forbidden foods and committing abominations will face God's judgment. It teaches the importance of holiness, obedience, and avoiding temptation. This aligns with practical Christian living in integrity and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 66:18-19 encourage believers in the mission of evangelism and sharing God's glory?
options: God will gather all nations to witness His glory and send messengers to declare it
Evangelism is optional and limited to Israel
God hides His glory from the nations
Only priests are responsible for sharing God's message
questions.correctAnswer: God will gather all nations to witness His glory and send messengers to declare it
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 affirm God’s plan to gather all peoples and send survivors as witnesses to proclaim His glory to distant nations. This encourages believers to actively participate in evangelism and trust God’s global purpose. It highlights God’s inclusive plan for salvation.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:20-21, what role does God assign to some of the people He gathers from the nations?
options: God will appoint some as priests and Levites
All will remain laypeople with no special roles
Only original Israelites will serve as priests
Priesthood will end with the old covenant
questions.correctAnswer: God will appoint some as priests and Levites
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:21 states that God will take some from the nations to serve as priests and Levites, showing His plan to include Gentiles in His holy service. This teaches the openness of God's kingdom and the call to faithful service in the church.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 66:22-23 reveal about the permanence of God's new creation and worship practices?
options: The new heavens and earth will remain, and all flesh will worship regularly
Worship will cease after the new creation
The old heavens and earth will be restored
Only a few will worship God in the new creation
questions.correctAnswer: The new heavens and earth will remain, and all flesh will worship regularly
questions.explanation: These verses promise the permanence of God's new creation and that worship will continue from one new moon to another and from one Sabbath to another. This encourages believers to cultivate consistent worship and faithfulness in anticipation of God's eternal kingdom.

questions.question: A believer questions how God deals with persistent sin among people. Based on Isaiah 66:24, what truth would you share?
options: Those who transgress against God face unending judgment and become an abhorrence
God quickly forgets all sins without consequence
Sin has no eternal consequences
Everyone will eventually be forgiven regardless of their choices
questions.correctAnswer: Those who transgress against God face unending judgment and become an abhorrence
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:24 describes the fate of those who have transgressed, whose corpses will be unconsumed by worms or fire, symbolizing eternal judgment. This teaches the seriousness of sin and the importance of repentance and obedience.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 66:1 teaches that God is limited to resting in a physical temple built by humans.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:1 states that heaven is God's throne and the earth His footstool, questioning where a human-built house could be His rest. This shows God’s sovereignty and that He is not limited to physical structures for His dwelling.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 66:6 describes a peaceful silence from the city and temple when God renders recompense to His enemies.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:6 describes a voice of noise from the city and temple as the LORD renders recompense to His enemies, indicating a powerful and active divine judgment, not silence.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 66:12 says, "Behold, I will extend peace to her like a ______, and the glory of the Gentiles like a flowing stream."
options: river
mountain
desert
fire
questions.correctAnswer: river
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:12 uses the simile of extending peace like a river to describe God's abundant and continuous blessing. This imagery encourages believers to trust in God's provision and peace flowing endlessly.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 66:23 encourage believers about the regularity and unity of worship?
options: All flesh will come to worship from one new moon to another and from one Sabbath to another
Worship is only occasional and individual
Worship will be discontinued in the new creation
Worship is limited to certain chosen people
questions.correctAnswer: All flesh will come to worship from one new moon to another and from one Sabbath to another
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:23 promises that worship will be continuous and unified, with all people coming before God regularly. This teaches the importance of consistent, communal worship in Christian life.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 66 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 66.

questions.question: In Isaiah 66:1, what metaphor does the LORD use to describe His sovereignty over heaven and earth?
options: The heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool
The earth is my throne, and the heavens are my sandals
The sea is my throne, and the mountains are my footstool
The stars are my throne, and the clouds are my footstool
questions.correctAnswer: The heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:1 uses the metaphor of the heavens as God's throne and the earth as His footstool, emphasizing God's supreme authority over all creation.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:2, to whom does the LORD particularly look with favor?
options: The poor and contrite in spirit who tremble at His word
The rich and powerful who offer many sacrifices
The learned and wise who interpret the law
The priests who maintain the temple rituals
questions.correctAnswer: The poor and contrite in spirit who tremble at His word
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:2 highlights God's preference for those humble and reverent before Him, contrasting with mere ritualistic obedience.

questions.question: Isaiah 66:3 provides a list of abominable practices. Which of the following is NOT mentioned as an abomination?
options: Offering swine's blood
Burning incense to idols
Eating locusts
Killing an ox as if slaying a man
questions.correctAnswer: Eating locusts
questions.explanation: The verse condemns certain sacrifices and offerings as abominable, but eating locusts is not mentioned in Isaiah 66:3.

questions.question: What consequence does the LORD declare for those who ignored His call in Isaiah 66:4?
options: He will choose their delusions and bring their fears upon them
He will forgive their sins and restore them
He will exile them to a foreign land
He will bless their descendants
questions.correctAnswer: He will choose their delusions and bring their fears upon them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:4 states that because they ignored God's call and did evil, He will bring delusions and fears as judgment.

questions.question: Isaiah 66:5 contrasts the fate of those who tremble at the LORD’s word with whom?
options: Their brethren who hated and cast them out for God's name's sake
The priests in the temple who profaned the sanctuary
Foreign kings who oppressed Israel
The idolaters of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Their brethren who hated and cast them out for God's name's sake
questions.explanation: The verse contrasts faithful ones with their brethren who rejected them, highlighting reversal of fortunes.

questions.question: In Isaiah 66:7-8, what miraculous event is described as a symbol of sudden national restoration?
options: A nation being born at once as a woman delivers a child before labor pains
The sun standing still for a day
The walls of Jerusalem falling down
A river turning to blood
questions.correctAnswer: A nation being born at once as a woman delivers a child before labor pains
questions.explanation: These verses use childbirth imagery to foreshadow the rapid and unexpected restoration of Zion.

questions.question: Which New Testament event or theme can Isaiah 66:7-8’s sudden birth imagery be connected to?
options: The virgin birth of Jesus Christ
The Pentecost outpouring of the Holy Spirit
The destruction of the temple in AD 70
The conversion of Cornelius
questions.correctAnswer: The virgin birth of Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: The imagery of a woman giving birth before labor is often typologically linked to the virgin birth of the Messiah.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:10-12, what are the people encouraged to do regarding Jerusalem?
options: Rejoice and be glad with her, suck and be satisfied with her consolations
Fast and mourn for her sins
Build new altars in her name
Offer sacrifices to foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoice and be glad with her, suck and be satisfied with her consolations
questions.explanation: These verses encourage joyful celebration and comfort in Jerusalem’s restoration and blessings.

questions.question: Isaiah 66:13 uses the simile 'As one whom his mother comforteth.' What theme does this convey?
options: God’s tender comfort and compassion toward His people
The necessity of strict discipline
The fear of divine judgment
The glory of the king’s palace
questions.correctAnswer: God’s tender comfort and compassion toward His people
questions.explanation: The verse portrays God's comforting presence as akin to a mother's soothing care.

questions.question: What imagery does Isaiah 66:15-16 use to describe the LORD’s coming judgment?
options: Fire, chariots like a whirlwind, sword, and flames
Water, rain, and thunder
Earthquake, darkness, and hail
Wind, sandstorm, and lightning
questions.correctAnswer: Fire, chariots like a whirlwind, sword, and flames
questions.explanation: These verses depict divine judgment with powerful, violent imagery emphasizing God's wrath.

questions.question: Isaiah 66:17 condemns certain practices involving purification and forbidden foods. Which animals are specifically mentioned as abominations?
options: Swine and the mouse
Eagles and locusts
Leopards and serpents
Camels and frogs
questions.correctAnswer: Swine and the mouse
questions.explanation: The verse condemns those who sanctify themselves yet eat swine’s flesh and mice, considered unclean in Hebrew law.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 66:18-19 reveal about God's plan for the nations and tongues?
options: God will gather all nations to see His glory and send survivors to declare it
God will destroy all nations without exception
God will isolate Israel from all foreign peoples
God will grant nations their own gods
questions.correctAnswer: God will gather all nations to see His glory and send survivors to declare it
questions.explanation: These verses announce a universal gathering and missionary sending, foreshadowing the global gospel mission.

questions.question: Isaiah 66:20 describes a diverse procession bringing offerings to Jerusalem. What is the significance of this imagery?
options: It symbolizes the restoration of Israel and the inclusion of Gentiles in worship
It depicts a military conquest of Jerusalem
It foretells the building of a new temple in Babylon
It predicts the exile of Israel to foreign lands
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the restoration of Israel and the inclusion of Gentiles in worship
questions.explanation: The verse speaks of a universal gathering of people bringing offerings, indicating restoration and expanded worship.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 66:21 connect to the Levitical priesthood and future worship?
options: God will take some for priests and Levites from among those gathered
The Levitical priesthood will be permanently abolished
Only foreigners will serve as priests
Priests will be selected from the tribe of Judah exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: God will take some for priests and Levites from among those gathered
questions.explanation: This verse promises a restoration or expansion of the priesthood from the gathered people.

questions.question: Isaiah 66:22 speaks of the new heavens and new earth. How does this relate to the permanence of God's covenant promises?
options: As the new heavens and earth remain, so shall your seed and name remain
The new heavens and earth will replace the descendants of Israel
The new heavens and earth will be temporary
The old covenant will continue despite the new creation
questions.correctAnswer: As the new heavens and earth remain, so shall your seed and name remain
questions.explanation: The verse ties cosmic renewal to the enduring legacy and covenant of God's people.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 66 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 66 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:1, what imagery does God use to describe His sovereignty over creation?
options: The heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool
The sea is my kingdom, and the mountains are my pillars
The stars are my crown, and the clouds are my chariot
The rivers are my veins, and the forests are my garment
questions.correctAnswer: The heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:1 depicts God's majesty and sovereignty by stating that heaven is His throne and earth His footstool, highlighting His supreme authority over all creation. This aligns with Psalm 103:19, 1 Kings 8:27, Matthew 5:35, and Acts 7:49 where God's sovereignty over heaven and earth is affirmed.

questions.question: In Isaiah 66:2, what kind of person does God say He will look to?
options: The rich and powerful
The poor and contrite in spirit who tremble at His word
The wise and learned
The strong and courageous
questions.correctAnswer: The poor and contrite in spirit who tremble at His word
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:2 emphasizes God's preference for humility and reverence over pride and self-sufficiency. This is consistent with Psalms 34:18, Isaiah 57:15, Matthew 5:3, and James 4:6 where God honors the humble and contrite.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 66:3 compare the act of killing an ox to?
options: As if he slew a man
As if he sacrificed a lamb
As if he destroyed a vineyard
As if he cursed the earth
questions.correctAnswer: As if he slew a man
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:3 likens killing an ox to murdering a man, indicating the gravity of false worship and abominable sacrifices. This concept relates to teachings in Leviticus 18:21, Jeremiah 7:31, Ezekiel 20:26, and Matthew 23:15 condemning improper worship practices.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:4, why will God bring fears upon the disobedient?
options: Because they ignored His calls and did evil before Him
Because they sacrificed on the altar
Because they did not fast
Because they built idols
questions.correctAnswer: Because they ignored His calls and did evil before Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:4 states that God will bring delusions and fears on those who ignored His call and chose evil, illustrating divine judgment. This is consistent with Hebrews 3:15, Proverbs 1:24-27, Romans 1:18, and John 12:48 about consequences of rejecting God's voice.

questions.question: In Isaiah 66:5, what will happen to the brethren who hated and cast out the faithful?
options: They shall be ashamed
They will receive blessings
They will inherit the land
They shall be exalted
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be ashamed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:5 promises that those who persecuted God's people will be ashamed when God appears for His servants' joy. This is echoed in Psalm 35:19, Matthew 5:11-12, Romans 8:17, and 1 Peter 4:14-16 where persecution is met with eventual vindication.

questions.question: What event is described in Isaiah 66:7-8 that symbolizes a miraculous birth?
options: Zion bringing forth her children in one day
The temple being rebuilt overnight
The rivers flowing backward
The sun standing still
questions.correctAnswer: Zion bringing forth her children in one day
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 describe Zion as a woman giving birth quickly, symbolizing sudden national restoration. This foreshadows messianic and eschatological fulfillment, similar to Isaiah 9:6, Luke 1:31-33, Romans 8:22-23, and Revelation 21:1 regarding new creation and salvation.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:10-11, what metaphor is used for the joy and satisfaction of Jerusalem's restoration?
options: Sucking and being satisfied with the breasts of her consolations
Eating the fruit of the vineyard
Riding upon the wings of eagles
Dancing before the altar
questions.correctAnswer: Sucking and being satisfied with the breasts of her consolations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:10-11 uses the metaphor of nursing to express nourishment and comfort from Jerusalem's blessings, reflecting God's care. Related passages include Psalm 131:2, Isaiah 49:15, John 6:35, and 1 Peter 2:2 which speak of spiritual sustenance.

questions.question: How does God describe His comfort for His people in Isaiah 66:13?
options: As one whom his mother comforteth
As a rock of refuge
As a shield from the storm
As a shepherd leading sheep
questions.correctAnswer: As one whom his mother comforteth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:13 likens God's comfort to that of a mother, emphasizing tender, personal care. This maternal imagery is echoed in Isaiah 49:15, Psalm 23:4, 2 Corinthians 1:3-4, and John 16:7-13 where God comforts His people through the Spirit.

questions.question: What will accompany the LORD's coming according to Isaiah 66:15?
options: Fire and chariots like a whirlwind
A gentle rain and a peaceful breeze
Thunder and earthquake
Angels singing loudly
questions.correctAnswer: Fire and chariots like a whirlwind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:15 portrays God's coming with fire and chariots like a whirlwind, signifying judgment and power. This is consistent with Exodus 19:18, 2 Thessalonians 1:7-8, Revelation 19:11-16, and Joel 2:1-11 describing divine judgment and glory.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:16, by what means will the LORD plead with all flesh?
options: By fire and by his sword
By thunder and lightning
By flood and famine
By angels and trumpets
questions.correctAnswer: By fire and by his sword
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:16 states that God will judge all flesh by fire and sword, indicating a righteous and purifying judgment. Similar language is found in Ezekiel 20:47, Matthew 10:34, Hebrews 12:29, and Revelation 1:16 emphasizing God's holiness and judgment.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 66:17 say about those who sanctify themselves by eating swine's flesh and other abominations?
options: They shall be consumed together
They shall be forgiven
They shall prosper
They shall be exalted
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be consumed together
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:17 condemns those who purify themselves through forbidden practices and declares they will be destroyed, reflecting God's holiness and judgment. This aligns with Leviticus 11, Deuteronomy 14:3-21, 2 Corinthians 6:14-18, and Revelation 21:8 regarding defilement and judgment.

questions.question: What does God promise in Isaiah 66:18 regarding the nations and tongues?
options: He will gather all nations and tongues to see His glory
He will scatter them abroad and confound their language
He will make them enemies of Israel
He will ignore them
questions.correctAnswer: He will gather all nations and tongues to see His glory
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:18 foretells a future gathering of all peoples to witness God's glory, indicating the universal scope of salvation. This corresponds with Psalm 86:9, Isaiah 49:6, Matthew 28:19, and Revelation 7:9 about the inclusion of Gentiles in God's kingdom.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 66:20, how will the brethren from all nations be brought to Jerusalem?
options: On horses, chariots, litters, mules, and swift beasts
On foot and by ship
By angels descending from heaven
By rivers and boats
questions.correctAnswer: On horses, chariots, litters, mules, and swift beasts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:20 describes a majestic procession bringing God's people to Jerusalem, symbolizing restoration and worship. This imagery is echoed in Zechariah 14:5, Matthew 24:31, Revelation 19:14, and Hebrews 12:22 portraying the gathering of God's redeemed.

questions.question: What role will God assign to some of the gathered people according to Isaiah 66:21?
options: Priests and Levites
Kings and judges
Prophets and scribes
Warriors and generals
questions.correctAnswer: Priests and Levites
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:21 states God will take some of the gathered for the priesthood and Levites, indicating a restored ministry. This is consistent with Exodus 28:1, Numbers 3:12, Hebrews 7:23-28, and 1 Peter 2:9 about God's appointed servants.

questions.question: Isaiah 66:22 compares the permanence of the new heavens and new earth to what?
options: The enduring seed and name of God's people
The mountains and hills
The stars in the sky
The rivers and seas
questions.correctAnswer: The enduring seed and name of God's people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 66:22 promises that just as the new heavens and earth endure, so will the descendants and name of God's people, emphasizing eternal covenant faithfulness. This is supported by Genesis 17:7, Psalm 72:17, Matthew 19:29, and 2 Peter 3:13.
